0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-unity-analysis-idUSKCN1010DP	"""Make Republicans Whole Again!"" A divided party struggles to rally behind Trump"	"
By Ginger Gibson and Emily Stephenson
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND Ted Cruz was recounting to an audience how he had outlasted most of his 16 rivals for the Republican presidential nomination when a plane carrying the man who had won it all
column2: Donald Trump
column3: flew overhead
column4: interrupting him mid-speech.""All right
column7: a Republican U.S. senator from Texas who waged a bitter campaign against Trump.Hours later Cruz would take his revenge
column8: refusing to endorse Trump and urging Republicans to vote their conscience during a prime-time speech on the floor of the Republican National Convention in Cleveland. He left the podium to a chorus of boos
column9: and his wife was escorted off the floor as the convention erupted in rancor.Susan Hutchison
column10: chair of the Washington state delegation
column11: said she confronted Cruz after his speech and called him a ""traitor to the party.""So much for party unity.Over three days in Cleveland this week
column12: Republican leaders sought to sell a story of unity. They repeatedly said the party was getting ever closer to rallying behind Trump
column13: who is running on the slogan ""Make America Great Again!"" and whose candidacy has divided many and exposed deep discontent among  Republicans with their leaders. But in a few minutes on Wednesday night that show of unity was blown apart in spectacular fashion.Cruz's non-committal speech infuriated Trump supporters among the thousands of delegates cramming the floor of the Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland. But their angry jeers triggered recriminations from other delegates.  ""They talk about unity and then they act like that. That is not going to get us to unify
column15: a Cruz delegate from Washington state. Trump will get the opportunity to rally the party when he formally accepts its nomination on Thursday night in a speech expected to be watched by millions of Americans
column16: including undecided and independent voters.WINNING OVER SKEPTICS

column1: One of Trump's key goals going into this week's convention was to unite the party after a roughly 18-month primary season that was marked by personal attacks on candidates
column2: sometimes violent rallies
column3: and deep disagreement over what it means to be a Republican.

column1: In public and in private the Trump campaign tried to win over skeptics who feel the New York businessman and celebrity TV star does not represent the party's values. It took a harder stance against opponents
column2: for example shutting down a desperate last-minute bid on the convention floor early in the week to stop his nomination. ""It's like a slow crawl
column3: former Republican National Committee Chairman Michael Steele said of the unity drive as he made the rounds at the convention. ""You're kind of doing it. You're kind of looking around to see if anyone else is doing it
column4: he told Reuters. But almost from the start there were blatant signs of party disunity. Ohio Governor John Kasich
column5: who lost to Trump in the nomination fight and disagrees with Trump on a host of issues
column6: declined to attend the convention held in his own state.Instead
column7: he greeted his supporters at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame close to the convention arena to the blaring tune of The Who's ""Baba O'Riley"" with lyrics like
column8: ""I don't need to fight to prove I'm right.""Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort told reporters that Kasich was ""embarrassing his state"" by refusing to get on the Trump train. His remarks were a reminder of the sort of insults that many Republicans had hoped would disappear after a brutal primary season that was characterized by Trump's often personal attacks on his opponents.

column1: PLEAS FOR UNITY
The pleas for unity were frequent in Cleveland
column2: led by House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column3: the top elected Republican
column4: who has been slow in warming to Trump.""What do you say that we unify this party at this crucial moment when unity is everything?"" Ryan asked thousands of convention attendees on Tuesday night. It was the biggest applause line of his speech - delegates cheered
column5: clapped and waved signs.But U.S. Senator Mike Lee of Utah
column7: is still not convinced. ""Federalism and separation of powers - if he focuses on that
column8: he brings along a lot of conservatives like me who haven't been sold yet
column9: Lee told Reuters. ""He needs to make that a distinct part of his message.""Trump and his surrogates have offered scant policy details so far at the convention
column10: nor have they been able to put to rest questions about whether they are capable of mounting a sophisticated presidential campaign to take on his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.

column1: The convention has been overshadowed
column2: for example
column3: by controversy surrounding his wife Melania's convention speech - which included lines uttered by first lady Michelle Obama at the Democratic convention in 2008 - and the campaign's initial reluctance to admit the plagiarism.Some Republicans thought it was an unnecessary distraction at a time when the party should be focused on selling itself and its new leader to Americans. Others said that if Trump was really serious about uniting the party he would reach out to his vanquished foes on the campaign trail
column4: including Cruz and Kasich.  Ken Cope
column5: a Texas delegate who had backed Cruz for president but will vote for Trump
column6: said the New York businessman needs to ""swallow his pride"" and stress the contributions his 16 defeated rivals made to the primary process instead of belittling them.""He's a prideful man and he's proud of what he is but we're in a general election campaign and it's going to take all of us pulling on the rope if we're going to pull the ship to the final line
column7: Cope said.Still others said Trump needed to be more disciplined.Trump supporter John Whitmer
column10: said Trump made a mistake by going on Fox News on Monday night to rail against Kasich as speakers were lauding his candidacy at the televised convention.""You just stepped on your best act
column11: Whitmer said. ""I get that you want to talk about Kasich
column12: but everybody needed to be watching what was going on there.""After Wednesday night
column13: the best hope for the Republican Party to come together may rest on Clinton
column14: who was frequently vilified at the Cleveland convention this week. She will be formally nominated as the Democratic presidential nominee at her party's convention in Philadelphia next week.When asked if the party was unified
column15: former Speaker of the House of Representatives and close Trump adviser
column18: but we will be by the end of Philadelphia.""""Trump will get us to 90 percent unity. She'll get us the rest of the way.""  (Additional reporting by Steve Holland and Amy Tennery in Cleveland and Chris Kahn in New York
column19: editing by Paul Thomasch and Ross Colvin)"	['Clinton'

column2: Vattenfall to build Scottish wind farm near golf resort	"

column1: STOCKHOLM Sweden's Vattenfall will invest 3 billion Swedish crowns ($349 million) in a Scottish offshore wind farm that U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump tried to stop being built near his luxury golf course in Scotland.State-owned utility Vattenfall
column2: which will take 100 percent ownership of the project from Aberdeen Renewable Energy Group
column3: described its investment as a vote of confidence in Britain after the nation's decision to leave the European Union.""The decision to invest ... comes only a few weeks after the British referendum on leaving the EU and demonstrates Vattenfall's continuing long-term commitment to wind power in Great Britain
column4: the company said in a statement.Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has said she would not rule out the possibility of Scotland remaining in the EU.Sturgeon said that a second independence referendum is now a possibility
column5: though she has also emphasized that another vote would not take place until it is clear that most Scots are in favor of breaking from the United Kingdom.

column1: Vattenfall said the wind farm will have capacity of 92.4 megawatts
column2: which could potentially supply about 130
column3: 000 households with energy. It will also serve as a center for testing and developing new technologies for offshore wind power.In December last year Britain's top court threw out a bid by Trump to stop the 11-turbine wind farm from being built near his multimillion-dollar resort.

column1: The Trump Organization had denounced the Scottish government as ""foolish
column2: small minded and parochial"". The Scottish National Party's foreign affairs spokesman Alex Salmond replied that Trump was ""three times a loser"".Construction is expected to start in the latter part of 2017
column3: with the wind farm expected to start generating electricity in spring 2018. Onshore construction activity will start later this year.

WASHINGTON The United States has an ""ironclad"" commitment to mutual defense among the NATO allies
column2: the White House said on Thursday after Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump raised questions about whether he would defend NATO allies if they were attacked.White House spokesman Josh Earnest declined to directly address Trump's comments to The New York Times but said potential foes should make no mistake or miscalculation about Washington's readiness to defend its NATO treaty allies.""The U.S. commitment to that pledge is ironclad
column3: Earnest told a briefing. ""The president renewed that commitment just two weeks ago today when he traveled to Warsaw
column4: Poland

column2: but said that solidarity among allies was a key value for the group.""This is good for European security and good for U.S. security
column3: the NATO head said in a statement. ""The United States has always stood by its European allies.""Stoltenberg's comments came after Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump raised fresh questions about his commitment to automatically defend NATO allies if they were attacked
column4: the New York Times reported.

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-hamm-exclusive-idUSKCN10100Z	Exclusive: Trump considering fracking mogul Harold Hamm as energy secretary - sources	"
By Michelle Conlin
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is considering nominating Oklahoma oil and gas mogul Harold Hamm as energy secretary if elected to the White House on Nov. 8
column2: according to four sources close to Trump's campaign.The chief executive of Continental Resources (CLR.N) would be the first U.S. energy secretary drawn directly from the oil and gas industry since the cabinet position was created in 1977
column3: a move that would jolt environmental advocates but bolster Trump's pro-drilling energy platform. Dan Eberhart
column4: an oil investor and Republican financier
column5: said he had been told by officials in Trump's campaign that Hamm
column6: who has been an informal advisor to Trump on energy policy since at least May
column7: was ""the leading contender"" for the position. Eberhart said he had discussed the possible appointment with  top donors at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland this week
column8: where Trump was formally nominated as the party's candidate in the Nov. 8 presidential election.Three other sources close to the Trump campaign confirmed Trump was considering Hamm for the post. One of the sources said he first heard that Hamm was a contender from Trump officials on Sunday. None of the sources was aware of who else Trump may be considering for the job.Representatives for Trump and Hamm did not respond to a request for comment. Addressing the convention on Wednesday night
column9: Hamm called for expanded drilling and said too much environmental regulation    threatened to limit U.S. oil production and increase the country's dependence on Middle Eastern oil producers.

column1: Every time we can't drill a well in America
column2: terrorism is being funded
column3: Hamm told the cheering crowd. ""Every onerous regulation puts American lives at risk.""    Hamm
column5: became one of America's wealthiest men during the U.S. oil and gas drilling boom over the past decade
column6: tapping into new hydraulic fracturing drilling technology to access vast deposits in North Dakota's shale fields.Past heads of the U.S. Department of Energy
column7: which is charged with advancing U.S. energy security and technology and dealing with nuclear waste disposal
column8: have typically boasted a political or academic background.This is not the first time Hamm has been in contention for the job.

column1: The Republican Party's presidential nominee in 2012
column2: Mitt Romney
column3: vetted Hamm to be energy secretary but ultimately decided against him because the two men have differing positions on renewable energy sources like wind. He made headlines in 2015 after settling a protracted divorce case and agreeing to pay his ex-wife $975 million - reported to be the biggest divorce settlement in history. His fortune is now estimated at nearly $12 billion.  ""FRACKER-IN-CHIEF""

column1: Trump
column2: who has yet to make any announcements about his prospective cabinet
column3: has already surrounded himself with strong advocates of traditional energy sources like oil
column4: gas
column5: and coal and has promised to gut environmental regulations to boost drilling and mining if elected.He tapped U.S. Congressman Kevin Cramer of North Dakota
column6: a climate skeptic and drilling advocate
column7: to help draw up his campaign energy platform
column8: and picked Indiana Governor Mike Pence
column10: as his running mate. Both moves cheered the energy industry but alarmed environmental activists who say a Trump presidency would set back years of progress on issues like pollution and climate change. ""Given that Hamm's as close as we've got to a fracker-in-chief in this country
column11: it would be an apropos pick for a president who thinks global warming is a hoax manufactured by the Chinese
column12: said leading environmental activist Bill McKibben. Trump's Democratic rival Hillary Clinton has promised to bolster regulation and increase use of renewable fuels to combat climate change if elected. (Writing by Richard Valdmanis
column13: editing by Paul Thomasch and Ross Colvin)"	['Trump'

column1: By Michelle Conlin and and Grant Smith
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column2: who gained popularity partly by bashing wealthy donors and vowing to fund his own campaign
column3: raised nearly as much money in June as the campaign of Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column4: according to federal reports filed on Wednesday.In the first month in which the Trump campaign's fundraising machine officially cranked up
column5: Trump raised nearly $20 million from individual donors other than himself
column6: as well as $2 million from donors to his joint fundraising committee with the Republican Party.The reports also showed that Trump converted the nearly $50 million in loans he made to his campaign into donations. He has $20 million in cash in the bank.

column1: Clinton's campaign brought in $24 million from individual donors during the same period
column2: and a further $11.5 million from donors to her joint fundraising committee.

column1: Trump's new money dash was also evident at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland this week
column2: where two Trump Super PACs - each dueling for supremacy and boasting a roster of marquee donors - held private events.Those in the donor class backing Trump include investor Foster Friess and casino magnate Sheldon Adelson
column3: who associates say is considering pouring as much as $100 million into helping Trump get elected.

column1: BEIJING China's Foreign Ministry on Thursday urged the U.S. Republican Party to stop making ""groundless accusations"" against China in its party platform
column2: which says China practices cultural genocide in Tibet and has ludicrous claims in the South China Sea.China's government has generally avoided making direct comments about the election
column3: wary of being seen to interfere
column4: though in April Chinese Finance Minister Lou Jiwei called Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump an ""irrational type"" due to his tariffs proposal on imported Chinese goods.In an English-language statement issued via the official Xinhua news agency on Thursday
column5: the ministry said the Republican platform contained ""accusations about China on issues related to Taiwan
column7: trade and the South China Sea"" and are an interference in China's internal affairs.""All political parties in the United States should view China's development in an objective and rational manner and correctly understand the issues that emerge in bilateral ties

column1: We hope relevant parties stop their groundless accusations against China and interference in China's domestic affairs and contribute more to bilateral trust and cooperation
column2: it added.The platform
column3: adopted on Monday
column4: says China has been asserting ""preposterous"" claims to the South China Sea to distract its people from economic problems
column5: practices ""cultural genocide"" in Tibet and Xinjiang
column6: and reaffirms a commitment to sell weapons to self-ruled Taiwan.

column1: China's foreign ministry said promoting stable growth in relations serves the interests of both countries and the peace and development of the Asia-Pacific region and the world
column2: and ""both sides should adhere to this right direction"".

column1: Chinese officials admit to knowing little about Trump compared with his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column2: who had extensive dealings with China when she was secretary of state. (Reporting by Ben Blanchard; Editing by Michael Perry)"	['Trump']	[]

By Adam DeRose and Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Democrat Hillary Clinton
column2: who is running against Republican Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 presidential election
column3: is expected to announce her running mate as early as Friday.Here are some of the potential vice presidential candidates Clinton is considering
column4: according to U.S. news media:TIM KAINE

column1: The U.S. senator from Virginia is a former Roman Catholic missionary and civil rights lawyer who is fluent in Spanish.Kaine
column2: a former Richmond mayor and former Virginia governor
column3: has served on the Senate's Foreign Relations and Armed Services committees.    He has backed liberal causes such as establishing a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. But
column4: like many Republicans and moderate Democrats
column6: a stance at odds with many party progressives.TOM VILSACK

column1: The U.S. agriculture secretary is a former governor of Iowa. During the primary

column3: speaking about his family's struggles with addiction and mental health. Clinton has promised to address those issues if elected.Vilsack
column4: a Pittsburgh native
column5: was orphaned and adopted as an infant. He settled in his wife's home state of Iowa.CORY BOOKER

column1: New Jersey's first black U.S. senator is a former Newark mayor. He was elected to the Senate in a 2013 special election and won re-election in 2014.Booker campaigned enthusiastically for Clinton
column2: including in the crucial early-voting state of New Hampshire during her primary race against Senator Bernie Sanders.ELIZABETH WARREN

column1: U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts is a fierce critic of Wall Street who spearheaded the creation of the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau after the global financial crisis. President Barack Obama tapped her to help set up the agency
column2: but congressional Republicans blocked her appointment.Warren is popular with progressives
column3: and was urged to run for president in 2016 but declined.She endorsed Clinton in June
column4: then joined her on the campaign trail.

column1: JAMES STAVRIDIS

The retired Navy admiral and former supreme allied commander of NATO is the dean of the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University near Boston.Stavridis worked closely with Clinton when he was at NATO and she led the State Department during Obama's first term.Though Stavridis would bring military heft to Clinton's ticket
column2: his role as a senior military official in the George W. Bush administration during the early years of the U.S. occupation of Iraq could provide Trump with a line of attack. Trump has criticized Clinton for
column3: as a U.S. senator
column4: voting for the 2003 U.S.-led invasion. SHERROD BROWN

column1: The U.S. senator from Ohio and former member of the U.S. House of Representatives is one of the Democratic Party's leading progressives.Brown was an early opponent of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement sought by the Obama administration
column2: describing it as a ""giveaway to corporations.""TOM PEREZ

column1: Obama's labor secretary has championed changes in regulations popular with organized labor and progressives. Perez reversed a regulation exempting domestic and home-care workers from overtime pay and extended overtime protections to some salaried workers by lowering the eligibility threshold. Perez has little campaigning experience
column2: however
column3: having only held one term on a county council from 2002 to 2006. JULIAN CASTRO

column1: The Department of Housing and Urban Development secretary is considered a rising Democratic star.Castro has pushed for expanding opportunities while serving as housing secretary
column2: including by broadening internet access across the country. But progressive groups have criticized his agency's sale of mortgage loans to big banks rather than non-profits during his tenure.A former San Antonio mayor
column3: Castro was elected as the city's youngest councilman at the age of 26.  (Reporting By Amanda Becker; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Sanders'
